conjugations.Notes: Present 1st person. SER is highly irregular. Used for permanent characteristics, identity, origin, profession.
Present 2nd person singular. Note the acute accent on '√©s'.
Present 3rd person singular. Very common form. '√â' is used for definitions, identity, time.
Present 1st person plural. One of the more regular-looking forms.
Present 3rd person plural. Also used for 'voc√™s'. Nasal '√£o' ending.

conjugations.English Translation: I went to the supermarket yesterday.
conjugations.Notes: Preterite 1st person. Completely irregular ‚Äî shares forms with IR (to go)! 'Fui m√©dico' (was) vs 'Fui ao m√©dico' (went).
Preterite 2nd person singular. Irregular form. Same as IR.
Preterite 3rd person singular. Same form as IR verb. Context determines meaning.
Preterite 1st person plural. Same as IR.
Preterite 3rd person plural. Same as IR. One of Portuguese's famous ambiguities.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Quando eu era crian√ßa, brincava muito.
conjugations.English Translation: When I was a child, I used to play a lot.
conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 1st person. Used for ongoing/habitual states in the past. One of the most useful tenses with SER.

conjugations.English Translation: You used to be very shy.
She used to be a teacher.
conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person ‚Äî context clarifies.
Imperfect 1st person plural. Note accent on '√©ramos'.

conjugations.English Translation: They used to be very happy.

conjugations.Notes: Future 1st person. Infinitive 'ser' + '-ei'. In casual speech, 'vou ser' is more common.

conjugations.English Translation: She will be the new director.
conjugations.Notes: Future 3rd person singular. Infinitive + '-√°'. Common in formal contexts: 'Ser√° que...?' = I wonder if...

conjugations.Example Sentence: Eu seria mais feliz em Portugal.
conjugations.English Translation: I would be happier in Portugal.
conjugations.Notes: Conditional 1st person. Infinitive + '-ia'. Used for hypotheticals. Very common in everyday speech.

conjugations.English Translation: You would be a good teacher.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Ela seria perfeita para o trabalho.
conjugations.English Translation: She would be perfect for the job.
conjugations.Notes: Conditional 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person.
Conditional 1st person plural. Note accent on 'ser√≠amos'.
Subjunctive 1st person. Irregular stem 'sej-'. Used after expressions of doubt, wish, emotion.
Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person. 'Seja' also used as 'so be it' / 'alright'.
Present 1st person. ESTAR is irregular. Used for temporary states, locations, conditions ‚Äî contrast with SER (permanent).
Present 2nd person singular. Note the acute accent on 'est√°s'.
Present 3rd person singular. Very common for describing feelings or locations.
Present 1st person plural. The most regular-looking form of ESTAR.
Present 3rd person plural. Nasal '√£o' ending, common in irregular verbs.
Preterite 1st person. Completely irregular stem 'estiv-'. For completed states in the past.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Ele esteve c√° na semana passada.
conjugations.Notes: Preterite 3rd person singular. Note 'esteve' not 'estiveu' ‚Äî irregular ending too.
Imperfect 1st person. Regular -AR imperfect. 'Estar a + infinitive' = continuous tense in European PT (not gerund!).
Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person ‚Äî context clarifies.
Imperfect 1st person plural. Note accent on 'est√°vamos'.

conjugations.English Translation: I will be there at eight.
conjugations.Notes: Future 1st person. Infinitive + '-ei'. In casual speech, 'vou estar' is more common.
Future 3rd person singular. Infinitive + '-√°'. More common in formal/written PT.

conjugations.English Translation: I would be there if I could.
conjugations.Notes: Conditional 1st person. Infinitive + '-ia'. For hypothetical situations and polite requests.

conjugations.English Translation: You would be better at home.

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person.
Conditional 1st person plural. Note accent on 'estar√≠amos'.
Subjunctive 1st person. Irregular stem 'estej-'. Used after doubt, wish, emotion expressions.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Duvido que ela esteja em casa.
conjugations.English Translation: I doubt she is at home.
conjugations.Notes: Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person.
Present 1st person. Irregular 'tenho'. TER is also auxiliary for compound tenses. Essential verb.
Present 2nd person singular. Short irregular form. 'Ter raz√£o' = to be right (idiomatic).
Present 3rd person singular. No accent in singular 'tem'.
Present 1st person plural. Most regular-looking form.
Present 3rd person plural. Circumflex accent 't√™m' distinguishes from singular 'tem'.
Preterite 1st person. Irregular stem 'tiv-'. Same pattern as ESTAR preterite.
Preterite 3rd person singular. 'Teve' not 'tiveu' ‚Äî irregular ending.
Imperfect 1st person. Irregular stem 'tinh-'. For habitual possession in the past.
Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person.
Imperfect 1st person plural. Note accent on 't√≠nhamos'.

conjugations.English Translation: I will have more time tomorrow.
conjugations.Notes: Future 1st person. Regular future despite irregular verb. Infinitive + '-ei'.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Tu ter√°s a resposta em breve.
conjugations.English Translation: You will have the answer soon.
We will have holidays in August.
I would have gone if I had known.
conjugations.Notes: Conditional 1st person. Infinitive + '-ia'. 'Teria + past participle' = compound conditional. Very important!
Conditional 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person.
Subjunctive 1st person. Irregular stem 'tenh-'. Mirrors present indicative 'tenho'.
Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same form as 1st person.
Present 1st person. Highly irregular. 'Vou + infinitive' = near future ‚Äî the MOST common way to express future!
Present 3rd person singular. One of the most-used words in Portuguese.
Present 1st person plural. 'Vamos!' = Let's go! Very common exclamation.
Preterite 1st person. SAME forms as SER preterite! 'Fui ao m√©dico' (went) vs 'Fui m√©dico' (was a doctor). Context is key.

conjugations.English Translation: Did you go to the party?
conjugations.Notes: Preterite 2nd person singular. Identical to SER.
Preterite 3rd person singular. 'Foi' = went OR was. Famous PT ambiguity.
Preterite 1st person plural. Same as SER.
Preterite 3rd person plural. Same as SER.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Eu ia √† escola todos os dias.
conjugations.English Translation: I used to go to school every day.
conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 1st person. Very short irregular form. Also 'was going to' (near past future).

conjugations.English Translation: You used to go to the park.
She used to go to the gym.
conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: We used to go to the beach in summer.
conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 1st person plural. Note accent on '√≠amos'.

conjugations.English Translation: They used to go to the caf√©.

conjugations.Notes: Future 1st person. Regular. In speech, 'vou ir' (going to go) is way more common than 'irei'.

conjugations.English Translation: Will you go to the concert?

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 1st person. Regular. 'Ia' (imperfect) is often used instead of 'iria' in casual speech.

conjugations.English Translation: Would you go to the doctor?
She would go if she could.
conjugations.Notes: Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: We would go to the party.

conjugations.Notes: Subjunctive 1st person. Highly irregular monosyllabic form.

conjugations.English Translation: I hope you go to the party.

conjugations.Notes: Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Subjunctive 1st person plural. Same form as indicative present!
Subjunctive 3rd person plural. Same form as indicative present.
Present 1st person. Irregular 'fa√ßo' (√ß only in 1st person). 'Fazer anos' = have a birthday (idiomatic).
Present 2nd person singular. Regular from here ‚Äî stem 'faz-' + -ER endings.
Present 3rd person singular. Also used for weather: 'Faz frio/calor' = It's cold/hot.
Preterite 1st person. Irregular stem 'fiz-'. The 'z' replaces the '√ß'.
Preterite 3rd person singular. 'Fez' ‚Äî note 'e' not 'i' in stem. Common exception.
Imperfect 1st person. Regular -ER imperfect! Despite being irregular, imperfect is regular.
Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: I will do what I can.
conjugations.Notes: Future 1st person. IRREGULAR ‚Äî stem contracts to 'far-' (not 'fazer-'). One of only 3 verbs with irregular future.

conjugations.English Translation: You will do a good job.
He will have his birthday in May.

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 1st person. Same contracted stem 'far-'. Irregular.
Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: We would do that for you.

conjugations.Notes: Subjunctive 1st person. Based on 1st person present 'fa√ßo' ‚Üí 'fa√ßa'. Common pattern.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Espero que tu fa√ßas o jantar.

conjugations.Notes: Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Espero que eles fa√ßam o certo.
conjugations.English Translation: I hope they do the right thing.

conjugations.Notes: Present 1st person. Irregular 'posso' ‚Äî stem changes to 'poss-' only in 1st person.
Present 2nd person singular. Regular from here ‚Äî 'pod-' + '-es'.
Present 3rd person singular. 'Pode ajudar-me?' = Can you help me? Very common polite request.
Preterite 1st person. Irregular stem 'pud-'. Often with negative 'n√£o pude'.
Preterite 3rd person singular. Circumflex 'p√¥de' distinguishes from present 'pode'.

conjugations.English Translation: We were able to solve it.

conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 1st person. Regular -ER imperfect. For 'could' in habitual sense or polite suggestions.
Imperfect 3rd person singular. 'Podia' also works as polite 'could you?'.

conjugations.English Translation: We could go to the cinema.
I will be able to go tomorrow.
You will be able to choose.
He will be able to help.
We will be able to try.
They will be able to come.

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 1st person. 'Poderia' = could (hypothetical). More formal than 'podia'.
Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Subjunctive 1st person. Based on 'posso' ‚Üí 'possa'. Irregular stem 'poss-'.
Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Present 1st person. Regular -ER pattern. Essential for ordering and expressing desires.
Present 2nd person singular. 'Queres ir?' = most common way to suggest doing something.
Present 3rd person singular. Irregular ‚Äî drops '-e'. 'Quer' not 'quere'.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Eu quis ir mas n√£o pude.
conjugations.English Translation: I wanted to go but couldn't.
conjugations.Notes: Preterite 1st person. Irregular stem 'quis-'. Same form as 3rd person!
Preterite 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person 'quis'.

conjugations.Example Sentence: Eu queria um caf√©, por favor.
conjugations.English Translation: I would like a coffee, please.
conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 1st person. Regular -ER imperfect. 'Queria' = THE polite ordering form in PT! Use at caf√©s and restaurants.

conjugations.English Translation: Did you want to go out?

conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Future 1st person. Regular but rarely used in speech. 'Vou querer' is preferred.
Future 3rd person singular. More common in writing.

conjugations.English Translation: I would want to go with you.
conjugations.Notes: Conditional 1st person. Regular but rarely used. 'Queria' (imperfect) is preferred for 'would like'.
Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: I hope I want to go.
I hope you want to come.

conjugations.Notes: Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Present 1st. MODEL -AR verb. Pattern: stem 'fal-' + '-o'. All regular -AR verbs follow this.
Present 2nd sg. Stem + '-as'. THE -AR pattern to memorize.
Present 3rd pl. Stem + '-am'. Don't confuse with '-√£o'.
Preterite 1st pl. Stem + '-√°mos'. Accent distinguishes from present.

conjugations.English Translation: You used to talk to her.
We used to talk about everything.
She will speak at the meeting.
They will talk about the plan.
I would speak if I could.

conjugations.Notes: -AR verbs switch to '-e' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -ER/-IR which use '-a').
Present 1st. MORAR = to reside. Contrast with VIVER (to live/exist). 'Morar em' = live in (place).
Present 3rd sg. Stem + '-a'. 'Morar em/no/na' = live in.
Preterite 1st pl. Stem + '-√°mos'. Accent distinguishes from present.

conjugations.English Translation: I used to live with my parents.
She used to live in the countryside.
We used to live in an apartment.
They used to live next door.
She will live in the center.
She would live near the beach.
They would live in the Algarve.

conjugations.Notes: -AR verbs switch to '-e' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -ER/-IR which use '-a').

conjugations.English Translation: I hope you live with me.

conjugations.Notes: Present 1st. Regular -AR. Note 'lh' digraph ‚Äî pronounced like 'lli' in 'million'.
Present 3rd sg. 'Trabalhar num/numa' = work in a (place).
Preterite 1st pl. Stem + '-√°mos'. Accent distinguishes from present.

conjugations.English Translation: I used to work in an office.
You used to work at night.
She used to work a lot.
They used to work in Porto.
She will work on the project.
They will work in the morning.

conjugations.Notes: -AR verbs switch to '-e' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -ER/-IR which use '-a').
Present 1st. GOSTAR always requires 'de' ‚Äî 'gostar de algo'. NEVER omit the 'de'!
Present 2nd sg. 'Gostas de...?' = Do you like...? Very common question.
Preterite 1st. 'Gostei do/da' ‚Äî contraction of 'de+o/a'. Essential with GOSTAR.

conjugations.English Translation: We used to like the beach.

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 1st. 'Gostaria de + infinitive' = 'would like to'. THE polite request form!
-AR verbs switch to '-e' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -ER/-IR which use '-a').
Preterite 1st pl. Stem + '-√°mos'. Accent distinguishes from present.

conjugations.English Translation: I used to buy at the market.
I would buy if I could.

conjugations.Notes: -AR verbs switch to '-e' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -ER/-IR which use '-a').
Present 1st. ANDAR also = 'to be (ongoing state)': 'Ando cansado' = I've been tired lately. Very useful!
Present 2nd sg. 'Andar de' + transport = go by. Super common construction.
Present 3rd pl. 'Andar de autocarro/metro/comboio' ‚Äî learn transport words!
Preterite 1st pl. Stem + '-√°mos'. Accent distinguishes from present.

conjugations.English Translation: You used to ride a bike.
We used to walk a lot.
They will walk in the garden.

conjugations.Notes: -AR verbs switch to '-e' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -ER/-IR which use '-a').
Present 1st. MODEL -ER verb. Stem 'com-' + '-o'. All regular -ER verbs follow this.
Present 2nd sg. Stem + '-es'. THE -ER pattern to memorize.
Preterite 1st pl. Stem + '-emos'. Same as present ‚Äî context clarifies!
-ER verbs use '-a' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -AR which uses '-e').
Present 1st. Regular -ER. Note: 'sumo' = juice in European PT (not 'suco' ‚Äî that's Brazilian!).
Preterite 1st pl. Stem + '-emos'. Same as present ‚Äî context clarifies!
-ER verbs use '-a' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -AR which uses '-e').
Present 1st person. Regular -ER. VIVER = to live/exist/be alive. Broader than MORAR (which is just residence).
Present 3rd person plural. Stem + '-em'. 'No estrangeiro' = abroad.
Preterite 1st person plural. Same as present ‚Äî context clarifies!

conjugations.English Translation: I used to live in Lisbon.

conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: We used to live in the countryside.
They used to live far away.
I would live in the countryside.

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
-ER verbs use '-a' endings in subjunctive (opposite of -AR).
Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Present 1st person. Regular -ER. 'Aprender a + infinitive' = to learn to do something.
Preterite 1st person plural. Same as present!

conjugations.English Translation: I used to learn at school.

conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: I would learn if I could.

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Present 1st person. MODEL -IR verb. Stem 'part-' + '-o'. PARTIR = to leave (a place) or to break (something).
Present 2nd person singular. Stem + '-es'. Same as -ER!
Present 3rd person singular. Stem + '-e'. -IR shares '-es'/'-e'/'-em' with -ER.
Present 1st person plural. Stem + '-imos'. KEY DIFFERENCE: -IR uses '-imos' not '-emos'.
Present 3rd person plural. Stem + '-em'. Same ending as -ER.
Preterite 2nd person singular. Stem + '-iste'. Note: '-iste' not '-este' (that's -ER).
Preterite 3rd person singular. Stem + '-iu'. Distinctive -IR ending.
Preterite 1st person plural. Same as present ‚Äî context clarifies!
Imperfect 1st person. Same as -ER imperfect! Stem + '-ia'.

conjugations.English Translation: She used to leave at six.
conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: They used to leave at night.
I would leave if I could.

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
-IR verbs use '-a' endings (same as -ER, opposite of -AR).
Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Present 1st person. Regular -IR. ABRIR has an irregular past participle: 'aberto' (not 'abrido').

conjugations.English Translation: We open the shop at nine.

conjugations.Notes: Preterite 1st person plural. Same as present.

conjugations.English Translation: I used to open the shop at eight.
You used to open the window.
She used to open the gifts.
conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.

conjugations.English Translation: They used to open the restaurant.

conjugations.Notes: Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Preterite 1st person plural. Same as present.

conjugations.English Translation: I always used to decide late.

conjugations.Notes: Imperfect 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Conditional 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
Subjunctive 3rd person singular. Same as 1st person.
